op-deployer: Fix intent validation with pre-deployed OPCM (#15712)

* op-deployer: Fix intent validation with pre-deployed OPCM

Previously, users were always required to provide the `SuperchainRoles` in their intent. Now that the intent supports providing an OPCM address, this is no longer necessary since we can look those values up on chain. The lookup was implemented in #15623, however users still had to provide `SuperchainRoles` in their intent to avoid validation errors.

The new logic is as follows:

- `standard` intents **must** specify the correct, standard OPCM address for the specified L1 and contracts version. Anything else is an error.
- All other intent types must **either** specify `SuperchainRoles`, or an OPCM address. Specifying both or neither will result in an error.
- The deployment pipeline will always pull `SuperchainRoles` data from the chain if the OPCM address is specified. Previously, it would only do this if the OPCM address was specified _and_ the L1 locator was a tag.

* cr updates

```
## 1. Purpose or design rationale of this PR

This PR updates the L1 data fee (aka rollup fee) to use a new formula starting at the Feynman upgrade.

Original formula (post-Curie): 

```
feePerByte = blobScalar * l1BlobBaseFee
l1DataFee(tx) = (commitScalar * l1BaseFee + feePerByte * size(tx)) / 1e9
```

New formula (post-Feynman):

```
feePerByte = execScalar * l1BaseFee + blobScalar

commits.message:
eth: fix canonical chain state inconsistency in checkpoint verifier

Add fallback logic to find potentialcommon ancestor using future milestones when
no whitelisted milestone exists in the current chain. Such scenario usually happens in a devnet.
This prevents nodes from getting stuck on wrong forks during milestone verification.

The issue occurs when nodes are on a fork and receive a new milestone:
- Existing logic only checks whitelisted milestones in current chain
- If current chain has no whitelisted milestones, rewind defaults to milestone start-1
- This can leave nodes on wrong fork instead of finding actual common ancestor

New logic adds findCommonAncestorWithFutureMilestones() which:
- Reads future milestone list from database (contains previously failed milestones)
- Searches from newest to oldest milestone to find matches with local chain
- Returns matching milestone block number to minimize rewind distance
- Falls back to calculated target block if no matches found

prs.title: chore: migrate execution client from reth to bera-reth (1/3)
prs.truncated_body:
## Summary
- Update local development docker image from `ghcr.io/paradigmxyz/reth:latest` to `ghcr.io/berachain/bera-reth:nightly`
- **Testnet and mainnet targets remain unchanged** using standard reth (bera-reth not production ready)
- Fix container path configurations for genesis files, data directories, and JWT secrets
- Add TODO comments for future bera-reth migration when production ready

##

commits.message:
chore: revert mainnet/testnet to standard reth

Keep bera-reth only for local development as it's not production ready.
Mainnet and testnet targets continue using paradigmxyz/reth.

chore: add TODO comments for future bera-reth migration

Mark testnet and mainnet targets for future migration to bera-reth
when it becomes production ready.

fix: add absolute paths for bera-reth compatibility

Bera-reth requires absolute paths (/) in container due to path resolution
differences from standard reth. Standard reth works with relative paths
but bera-reth needs absolute paths to locate genesis files and data dirs.

Added documentation comment explaining this difference.

docs: document bera-reth path resolution bug

Added detailed comments explaining the root cause of the path resolution
issue in the custom reth fork at chainspec.rs:71. The parse_genesis function
uses shellexpand::full() but doesn't resolve relative paths to absolute paths,
causing failures in Docker containers when the working directory differs.

fix: revert to relative paths after bera-reth path resolution fix

The path resolution bug in bera-reth has been fixed in the latest
Docker image. This removes the need for absolute paths (/) in
container arguments, reverting all paths back to relative paths
to match the original reth configuration.

- Remove absolute path documentation comments
- Revert all Docker container paths to relative format
- Update to fixed bera-reth image tag

fix: update to bera-reth Docker image in testing.mk

Replace paradigmxyz/reth with berachain/bera-reth:nightly
to use the custom Berachain execution client that includes
path resolution fixes and Berachain-specific features.

chore: keep mainnet/testnet on standard reth with TODO

Revert mainnet and testnet reth configurations back to standard
paradigmxyz/reth with TODO comments for future bera-reth migration
once it's production ready for these networks.

feat: update prague1 activation timestamp and add berachain config

Update prague1 activation timestamp to 17446744073709551614 across
all genesis files except mainnet/testnet. Add berachain configuration
to additional genesis files for consistency.

fix: use bera-reth CLI commands in Kurtosis configuration

Update Kurtosis reth configuration to use bera-reth CLI commands
instead of standard reth commands for consistency with the
bera-reth Docker image.

feat: add berachain config to Kurtosis genesis templates

Add berachain configuration section with prague1 fork timing
to Kurtosis template files for consistent e2e testing setup.

prs.title: feat(fortuna): Multiple replica support
prs.truncated_body:
## Summary

Implemented multiple Fortuna replica support with modulo-based request assignment and configurable backup delays.

## Rationale

We want to improve Fortuna's reliability through redundancy, but naively running multiple Fortuna instances caused race conditions and gas waste. Now we distribute requests to specific replicas via `sequence_number % total_replicas`. All replicas still

commits.message:
feat(fortuna): implement multiple replica support with sequence number modulo filtering

Co-Authored-By: Tejas Badadare <tejas@dourolabs.xyz>

feat(fortuna): add delayed processing for backup replicas

- Add configurable time delay before backup replicas check request status
- Backup replicas now wait backup_delay_seconds before attempting fulfillment
- Add backup_delay_seconds field to ReplicaConfig with default of 30 seconds
- Improves reliability by reducing race conditions between replicas

Co-Authored-By: Tejas Badadare <tejas@dourolabs.xyz>

docs(fortuna): add comprehensive multi-replica setup documentation

- Add Multiple Replica Setup section to README.md with modulo assignment explanation
- Add replica_config examples to config.sample.yaml for 2, 3, and 5 replica setups
- Include deployment considerations, failover behavior, and wallet separation requirements
- Add validation for backup_delay_seconds > 0 to prevent race conditions

Co-Authored-By: Tejas Badadare <tejas@dourolabs.xyz>

refactor(fortuna): streamline keeper configuration and improve event processing

- Updated config.sample.yaml by removing unnecessary blank lines.
- Changed backup_delay_seconds in README.md from 45 to 30 for consistency.
- Refactored run_keeper_threads to accept KeeperConfig directly instead of private_key.
- Enhanced run function to handle keeper configuration more effectively.
- Added comments in process_event_with_backoff to clarify primary and backup replica logic.

commits.message:
Remove MODE_ENABLES_BUCKETLIST configuration option

This removes the MODE_ENABLES_BUCKETLIST config flag that was previously
used to conditionally enable/disable bucket list functionality. The bucket
list is now always enabled as it's a core component of Stellar Core.

Changes:
- Remove MODE_ENABLES_BUCKETLIST declaration from Config.h
- Remove initialization and usage from Config.cpp
- Update BucketManager to always create bucket lists without conditional checks
- Update LedgerManagerImpl to always use bucket lists
- Update NetworkConfig to always get bucket list size
- Update HistoryManagerImpl to always get bucket list
- Remove the flag from CommandLine minimal mode configuration

## Why this should be merged

We have a metric that measures the time between building the block to accepting it. However it uses the block's timestamp. This value includes the time the VM builds a block as we need to compute the time and insert the time into the block before we build it.

To better compute the time between right before the block builder releases the block to the network and t

prs.title: [tmpnet] Run kube load test under a service account to validate RBAC
prs.truncated_body:
## Why this should be merged

Running tmpnet in a pod (as is intended for the load test) requires that the pod run under a service account with sufficient permissions for the tmpnet kube runtime to operate. To validate the RBAC configuration, the task running the load test under kube has been updated to execute with the set of RBAC permissions that tmpnet requires.
